user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_destroy_response:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN void
MHD_destroy_response (struct MHD_Response *response)
{
  struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header *pos;

  if (NULL == response)
    return;
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&response->mutex);
#endif
  if (0 != --(response->reference_count))
  {
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
    MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&response->mutex);
#endif
    return;
  }
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&response->mutex);
  MHD_mutex_destroy_chk_ (&response->mutex);
#endif
  if (NULL != response->crfc)
    response->crfc (response->crc_cls);

  if (NULL != response->data_iov)
  {
    free (response->data_iov);
  }

  while (NULL != response->first_header)
  {
    pos = response->first_header;
    response->first_header = pos->next;
    free (pos->header);
    free (pos->value);
    free (pos);
  }
  free (response);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I inspected the provided function for compiler/language extensions explicitly present in the source text. The code contains no explicit compiler-specific extension tokens or constructs that are documented as extensions (examples that would be reported: __attribute__ ((...)), __declspec(...), __asm, asm(...), typeof(...), GNU statement expressions ({ ... }), __builtin_* intrinsics, __extension__, _Pragma with implementation-specific pragmas, Microsoft-specific extensions like __fastcall, etc.).

Notes on potentially concerning identifiers that are NOT reported:
- _MHD_EXTERN appears as a macro name, but the source does not show its expansion. The macro name itself is not an explicit language extension in the code fragment shown; any extension would only be visible in its definition, which is not part of the supplied code. Therefore it is not reported here.
- Identifiers with trailing or leading underscores (for example MHD_mutex_lock_chk_) are ordinary identifiers in the fragment; reserved-identifiers rules or naming conventions are not the same as compiler language extensions and are outside the scope of Rule 1.2 as specified here.
- Preprocessor conditionals (defined(...)) and calls to standard library routines (free) are standard C and not extensions.

Because no explicit compiler extension constructs are present in the shown code, there are no suspicious fragments to flag for Rule 1.2 based on the provided source alone.
